Description: Fragment of the necking of a limestone column with meander decoration. The fragment is probably from the top of a column necking with an even zone with a meander decoration. Below, another even zone appears which shows traces from possibly turning. On top of this a 0.60 cm high section that leads over to the meander zone which is slightly withdrawn on its vertical cross-section (0.5 mm). This smoothed zone had initially an incised rectangle grid: vertical line distance 6.3 mm, horizontal distance 5.5 mm. This grid was used as the base for a two row swastika meander, albeit a third row is assumed by the little remains on the upper edge. The meander is ca. 2mm high, while the intermediate spaces were ca. 4.5 to 5 mm deepened. The axis dimension of the ornament is 5.5 cm. Traces of red paint were found on the rock spurs. The fragment was made of a soft and light yellowish limestone.
Curator's comments: The axis dimension of the ornament is 5.5 cm, whereby following diameter of the meander zone can be concluded: 26 axes -> Dm 45.5 cm, or 28 axes -> Dm 49 cm. After controlling with a circle template a diameter of 46.6 cm with around 26 axes has resulted. According to Koenigs 2007, the fragment could have belonged to an Ionian votive column of ca. 4.5-5.5m height. Published (Koenigs 2007, 345f. Cat. 44; Petrie 1886, 16; Bissing 1951, 65; Moeller 2000, 103f.)
Found in 1884, though the temple itself was not indentified until the following year.
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B435)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (p. 345-6, cat. no. 44, pls. 23, 28)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.62) (Phase 3)
